skill.name: Draft a Commit
skill.description: Create a thoughtful, supportive commit message from your staged changes.
skill.summary: Create a thoughtful, supportive commit message from your staged changes.
skill.author: AbeJitsu

security_audit.summary: This is a pure prompt-based skill with no executable code. It only reads local configuration and git diff output. No network access, no command execution, no data exfiltration.

content.user_title: Draft commit messages from staged changes
content.value_statement: Writing good commit messages is hard. This skill analyzes your staged changes and creates clear, descriptive commit messages that explain what changed and why it matters.
actual_capabilities: Analyzes staged git changes with git diff --cached
Generates commit messages in supportive or concise style
Supports descriptive and conventional commit formats
Reads local config.json for customizable behavior
Provides context about why changes matter
Shows file and line change statistics

use_cases.title: Write clearer commit history
use_cases.description: Create meaningful commit messages that help future you understand what was done and why

use_cases.title: Maintain consistent messaging
use_cases.description: Follow team conventions with conventional commits format support for better changelog generation

use_cases.title: Improve contribution quality
use_cases.description: Draft professional commit messages that meet project contribution guidelines

prompt_templates.title: Basic draft
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the draft-commit skill to create a commit message from my staged changes

prompt_templates.title: Conventional format
prompt_templates.prompt: Run the draft-commit skill with conventional format to create a standardized commit message

prompt_templates.title: Detailed context
prompt_templates.prompt: Use draft-commit with detailed message length and full context to explain my changes thoroughly

prompt_templates.title: Brief summary
prompt_templates.prompt: Run draft-commit with concise style and no file counts for a quick summary commit message

output_examples.input: Use the draft-commit skill to create a commit message from my staged changes
output: Implements JWT-based authentication for API. Includes token generation, validation, and refresh logic.
Changes analyzed: 3 files changed, +150 lines added, -23 lines deleted

best_practices: Stage changes intentionally before running this skill
Review and edit the drafted message before committing
Configure style and format to match your project conventions
anti_patterns: Relying on it without understanding your own changes

faq.question: What tools does this work with?
faq.answer: Compatible with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. Works in any git repository.

faq.question: How long can commit messages be?
faq.answer: Configure concise or detailed length in config.json based on your team preferences.

faq.question: How do I integrate with my workflow?
faq.answer: Stage changes with git add, run the skill, copy the message, then commit manually.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill runs locally, reads only staged changes, and sends nothing externally.

faq.question: What if the message is wrong?
faq.answer: The skill generates a draft for you to review and edit before using in your commit.

faq.question: How is this different from AI commit tools?
faq.answer: This skill focuses on clarity and context, not just summarizing changes. You stay in control.
